comments.commentBody:
It's ironic and sad:

"This time, it’s the Republican businessman who has positioned himself as the candidate fighting for ordinary Americans. He has adopted positions with real appeal to working-class Democratic-leaners, whether on trade, immigration or the social safety net. Mrs. Clinton, on the other hand, is the one being caricatured as Mr. Romney was: as corrupt and bought by special interest and corporations."

The businessman who lies, cheats, commits fraud, evades income taxes and violates laws against "self-dealing" (using his charity foundation!), dodges publishing tax returns and puts jobs overseas appeals better than a longstanding public servant who puts her name to good use for her charity foundation that actually helps people all over the world?

Only in America!

Hill had been at the front lines for all minorities , Blacks,Hispanics ,women and children for her entire life!
Oppressed peoples worldwide can trust Hillary Clinton as President of these United States

The debates never should be based on current polls but on who is going to be on the ballot in all 50 states. The only people that meet that criteria are Clinton, Johnson, and Trump. Gary Johnson should have been included no matter what the polls say. The poll is not the election. If a voter is asked "if you vote today, who would you pick" the problem is that the ELECTION IS NOT TODAY. The debate should not be a popularity contest but a means to educate the American voter.

Why is there a cutoff? The reason is that the Commission on Presidential Debates is BIPARTISAN not NONPARTISAN. It is a partnership between Republicans and Democrats (look it up on Wikipedia). Help the voter make an informed decision - include Gary Johnson.

I just love how you talk about the extensive support for what you term "minor party candidates" while studiously avoiding saying the name of the candidate who, according to the latest NBC News / Surveymonkey weekly tracking poll is leading both Clinton and Trump among independents. So let me say it for you. Gary Johnson. Gary Johnson. Gary Johnson.

comments.userLocation: up in the woods down by the river
comments.commentBody:
Mrs. Clinton has the same problem as Rudy Giuliani. The more people hear her speak the lower she falls in the polls. Which makes her decline almost impossible to reverse. And that is why the Dems should not have rigged the primaries in her favor. She's not a great candidate. And candidly, was she really such a great senator or Secretary of State?

Trump made himself impossible to ignore. But ignoring the other candidates has always been her best strategy. She and her campaign could be making a mistake by giving him the time of day. She didn't need to. It elevates him.

If there were more ...set standards.
.for running for.... and holding office.
.especially this office
Full disclosure of tax returns....a real vetting of a persons past in many aspects... including financial and business dealings
Real fact checking
....with real repercussions after many mis/false statements ( including outright dishonest lies)
standards for decorum..and civility while engaging in campaigning...
standard debate procedures...known to all

It would make it easier to judge the candidates
call it "A Candidates Rights and Responsibilities"

One half of the people who go to the polls in November, plus or minus a small fraction, will vote for Trump precisely because they perceive (or hope) that he hates blacks, Muslims and Mexicans. Whether he wins or loses, this is the reality of America, a schizophrenic country comprising two diametrically opposing factions wherein common ground for rational discourse has disappeared.

The frightening but not so obvious thing about the polls that are dominating the political conversation is that hacking pollster databases can be a very powerful weapon for the enemies of the U.S. and western democracy in general.

If voters feel their candidate is slipping in the polls, they begin to question whether they're backing the right candidate. If they think their candidate is likely to lose, they may not even bother to vote. Doubtless this strategy of skewing poll results has occurred to those clever hackers in Russia and China.

It should be asked how well guarded from tampering are the DATABASES containing poll results. Many polls are administered by academic or media organizations without military-grade security and not accustomed to defending against well-hidden, weaponized hacks by state-sponsored agents.

In a tight election, manipulating a poll even by a few percentage points can completely tip the balance in favor of the losing candidate - with all the attendant publicity and media coverage of "winning in the polls".

So a not particularly difficult hack, but one with highly significant power for media manipulation.

Trump now leads in key states like Ohio in the latest polls.Hillary is snatching defeat from the jaws of victory.Why?Here are some examples.One,the "rope off" of journalists during the NH parade.Two,all her 6 figure speeches.Three,the e mail fiasco.Four,the Clinton Foundation misuse of funds.Five,health issues.Six,people don't trust her.And seven,people just don't like her.

replies.commentBody: The republic will only hold if you're white.

comments.commentBody:
I heard this last week while in the PA factory ... the only thing that scares me more than Trump .... Clinton

It's that simple.

People know what they are going to get with HRC .. they don't want it. Trump scares them .. but they trust the republic will hold together. Many believe we need a house cleaning .

Why do I get the feeling that this journalist is biased for Hillary Clinton in this election? I guess the news media is not known for reporting the news. This is more of a campaign office, trying to rationalize the polls with other Clinton supporters.
How KelleyAnn Conway  can sleep at night is beyond me.

This phrase is Trump's key to victory: "Clinton is just as bad as Trump. I can't bring myself to vote for either of them."

This is my alternative to Nate Cohn's theories. Clinton's decline has to do with further waves of false equivalence between the two candidates. Trump's campaign, again, seems to be one step ahead of the media and the Clinton campaign. Trump and Clinton still seem to think Trump's ignorance, lies, and narrow white nationalist appeal will still catch up to him before the election. But I believe they are wrong.

This is why Trump seems to make so few efforts to change his ways. It's because Trump can win with the followers he already has.

That is, if potential Clinton voters stay home. Trump is popular among older, white voters. Historically, it is a demographic that votes reliably. In contrast, Clinton needs to mobilize young voters and lower-income minority voters. These demographics vote in small numbers historically, and is often the target of voter suppression.

So Trump doesn't need to re-brand or change himself. He and his campaign simply relentlessly attack Clinton. His surrogates continuously encourage false equivalence between Trump and Clinton, and the mainstream media obligingly plays along. This is all to make sure enough people hate Clinton enough to stay home on election day.

How anyone can take Trump seriously is beyond me.

And I have friends and neighbors in that group.

Of course, some of those still believe the Clintons had Vince Foster murdered so I shouldn't be surprised.

On the other hand, it is the right-wing media that over years of misinformation have helped to give us Trump. And now serious Republicans know they have a mess on their hands with Trump. They know the future of this country and their children and grandchildren is at stake.

They should have thought about that years ago.

replies.commentBody: Gary Johnson should have been included in the debates.  They are not a popularity contest.  If he is on all 50 state ballots, he should be in the debate.  Only Johnson, Clinton and Trump are on all 50 state ballots.

comments.commentBody: I think the "undecided" aspect comes down to the fact that disliking one candidate does not mean that you'll end up liking the other. I never considered voting for Trump for a second, but I'm still not thrilled about Hillary. Yes, I understand that with things so close, to vote for a 3rd party or not to vote at all, would be unwise. But, I'm still not thrilled about her. I think my biggest concern comes from the way she handled her husband's alleged abuse of other women. Yes, I know she's his wife, but she's also a woman. So, to take his side so completely feels somehow traitorous to the fact that sex crimes against women are such a pressing issue in this country. Ultimately, I guess I feel like a condition of my enthusiastic support (for anybody) would really be that you understand that nobody is above the law -- not you, not your husband or wife, not your family...no one. Yes, I know, Trump is at least the same if not worse in this regard. But, that doesn't make Hillary seem like a good choice. It still leaves us with the "lesser of two evils" -- and that is not something which entails enthusiasm. Not for me, anyway...

Spin it any way you want, Nate, but the fact remains that Hillary is the worst, most un-liked, most painfully and obviously corrupt candidate the Democratic party has ever nominated for president in the past 60 years. She can't even hold a lead against a buffoon rejected by his own party leaders. She is where she is only by the sheer force of behind-the-scene exertions of power and what appears to be election fraud. She's a nightmare. That's why she is in a dead heat.

The real underlying reason for Trumps existance is the failure of the Establishmnet Republican Party.  They have failed to connect to a big part of their constituency, working people.  The Republican Party paid no attention to them.  There was no central theme that appealed to the "overlooked".  The "overlooked"  don't care about tax reduction, a big proportion of them don't pay taxes.  What they care about is good jobs, increasing paychecks, they can't connect with the Republican Party because conservative values don't put food on the table.  Clinton has been so badly mauled by Republicans over the years, that she has become a target for working class frustration, when in reality she represents their interests better then anyone else.  Trump stepped in and combined some Republican ideas, democratic ideas with fantasy and incredible gall.  His style appealed to these folks because he spoke their language anger and frustration.  I hope Hillary wins,  but we can blame the "stand for nothing " Republicans for the  possibility of a Trump presidency.
One of these two horrible candidates will be our next President.  Thankfully it will be for one short four year term.  America can survive this and look forward to 2020.
Choosing between a liar and a truth-teller is easy. Choosing between two proven liars makes it hard. Thus the conundrum of Election 2016. Hopefully by 2020 we'll have better options.

Trump has ... er.... 'touched the cord' of the working class voter. Unfortunately for him, not many have come to terms to vote for him.

We live in a parallel universe and automatically call out working class problems as results of laziness. But the issues are deeper.

If Trump were to be less Trump or if Sanders won the nomination, the election would have been over long ago.
There's a rebound effect in play from the media barrage..more of those polled are thinking "he can't be that bad."  Whether that continues depends on his tenor tonight.

Will the authorities admit that the Washington shooting was a terror attack?  And was the Houston shooting really just a matter of a lawyer with "issues?"  I do think these issues and the appropriate label are being downplayed because they don't fit the Hillary narrative.  To admit these attacks were indeed terror attacks boosts Trump's numbers.

This is where we see the power of media and how perception drives an insane reality of a close race. It shouldn't be even close ....
The ground game will need to be factored in and this is where Hillary is far ahead of the curve...

In any case, if you care for your country, register and vote for her. There is only one choice and I trust her !

If Clinton gets closer to Sanders, adopts more of his policies and disavows more of her former ones (and distances herself more from moneyed interests), she just might reel those young and working class voters in -- but it will be hard for her to convince them of her sincerity or commitment to those policies and values.
I'd lie to see Gennifer Flowers seated between Mark Cuban and Bill Clinton
